title: CONTRIBUTING
text: reporting Issue, please spend time making easy follow reproduce issue. , highly recommend using reprex package. can also start new Discussion resolve issue share new ideas.

title: CONTRIBUTING
text: good way start contributing additional examples improving documentation. Additionally, can submit Pull Request integrate function(s) new branch. want submit new function please provide: new function(s) code roxygen tags (examples) shown {r} #' Add together two numbers #'  #' @param x number. #' @param y number. #' @return sum \code{x} \code{y}. #' @examples #' add(1, 1) #' add(10, 1) add <- function(x, y) {   x + y }

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Let \(X_1\) denote model matrix main-effects model (including intercept) let \(X_2\) denote model matrix corresponding two-factor interactions. Suppose true model \[ Y = X_1 \beta_1 + X_2 \beta_2 + \epsilon \] \(\epsilon\) vector residuals \(\mathbb{E}(\epsilon)=0\), \(\beta_1\) vector consisting intercept main effects coefficients \(\beta_2\) vector consisting two-factor interactions effects coefficients. experimenter employs main effects model estimation, well known expected value least squares estimator \(\hat{\beta}_1\) \(\beta_1\) \[ \mathbb{E}(\hat{\beta}_1) = \beta_1 + \beta_2 \] \(\) alias matrix. define alias matrix \(\) \[ = (X_1^T \, X_1)^{-1} \  X_1^T X_2 \] One can view color map absolute value correlations among main effects two-factor interaction columns using function alias_matrix()  functions ggDoE one can choose display plot return data/calculations used construct plot using showplot=FALSE argument. example, can simply return correlation matrix (absolute) among main effects two-factor interactions follows

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Box-Cox transformation transformation response variable often normally distributed, one follow approximately normal distribution. transformation performed follows \[ y(\lambda) = \begin{cases} \frac{y^\lambda -1}{\lambda}, & \text{} \, \lambda \neq 0 \\ \log y, & \text{} \, \lambda =0 \end{cases} \] “optimal value” \(\lambda\) one results best approximation normal distribution curve. common Box-Cox transformations  figure, “optimal value” \(\lambda=0.253\). good transformation perform \(\log(y)\). results can extracted using showplot=FALSE argument, needed. transformation doesn’t always work well, make sure check diagnostics model transformed response. See diagnostic_plots().
code: model <- lm(s2 ~ (A+B+C+D),data = adapted_epitaxial) boxcox_transform(model,lambda = seq(-5,5,0.2)) boxcox_transform(model,lambda = seq(-5,5,0.2),                  showplot = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   best_lambda lambda_low lambda_high #>         <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1       0.253      -3.99        4.70

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Obtain trace plot t-statistics calculated effect model applying Box-Cox transformation across specified sequence lambda values  alternatively,

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Using gg_boxplots() constructs boxplots making easy visually compare shape, central tendency, variability samples.  can group sample using group_var argument, argument must unquoted. color_palette can change color palette boxplots. color_palette eight options available: “viridis”,“cividis”,“magma”,“inferno”,“plasma”,“rocket”,“mako”,“turbo”. Lastly, one can overlay jittered points boxplot using jitter_points=TRUE.
code: data <- ToothGrowth data$dose <- factor(data$dose,levels = c(0.5, 1, 2),                     labels = c("D0.5", "D1", "D2")) head(data) #>    len supp dose #> 1  4.2   VC D0.5 #> 2 11.5   VC D0.5 #> 3  7.3   VC D0.5 #> 4  5.8   VC D0.5 #> 5  6.4   VC D0.5 #> 6 10.0   VC D0.5 gg_boxplots(data,x = 'dose',y = 'len') gg_boxplots(data,x = 'dose',             y = 'len',             group_var = 'supp',             color_palette = 'viridis',             jitter_points = TRUE)

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Residual vs. Fitted Values Normal-QQ plot Scale-Location plot Residual vs. Leverage Cook’s Distance Collinearity default plots gg_lm() first four list mentioned . However, one can choose six plots need. example one needs six plots use which_plots=1:6.  Another example, one simply requires Residual vs. Fitted Values Cook’s Distance plots, use which_plots = c(1,5). one wants display confidence intervals, use standard_error=TRUE
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ wt + am + gear + vs * cyl, data = mtcars) gg_lm(model, which_plots=1:6) gg_lm(model, which_plots=c(1,5),       standard_errors = TRUE)

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Half-Normal plot graphical tool used help identify experiment factors significant effects response. addition, cutoff line(s) added margin error () simultaneous margin error (SME) effects. values obtained using unrepx::().  method argument seven construction methods obtain pseudo standard errors order calculate () (SME). methods “Daniel”, “Dong”, “JuanPena”, “Lenth” (Default), “RMS”, “SMedian”, “Zahn”, “WZahn”. See ?ggDoE::half_normal details references methods.  can change significance level used obtain () (SME) determine factors active using alpha argument. Default alpha=0.05. Using label_active argument label active factors experiment. Using showplot=FALSE return needed information reproduce/change half-normal plot
code: m1 <- lm(lns2 ~ (A+B+C+D)^4,data=original_epitaxial) half_normal(m1) half_normal(m1,method='Daniel',alpha=0.1,             ref_line=TRUE,label_active=TRUE,             margin_errors=TRUE) half_normal(m1,method='Daniel',alpha=0.1,             showplot=FALSE) #> # A tibble: 15 × 3 #>    effects absolute_effects half_normal_quantiles #>    <chr>              <dbl>                 <dbl> #>  1 A:D              0.00197                0.0418 #>  2 C                0.0768                 0.126  #>  3 B                0.0783                 0.210  #>  4 A:B:D            0.0858                 0.297  #>  5 A:B:C:D          0.109                  0.385  #>  6 A:C              0.214                  0.477  #>  7 B:D              0.305                  0.573  #>  8 B:C:D            0.314                  0.674  #>  9 B:C              0.331                  0.784  #> 10 A:B:C            0.335                  0.903  #> 11 A:B              0.428                  1.04   #> 12 A:C:D            0.494                  1.19   #> 13 C:D              0.582                  1.38   #> 14 D                0.632                  1.64   #> 15 A                3.83                   2.13

what: Interaction Effects Plot for a Factorial Design
title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Interaction effects plot two factors factorial design
code: interaction_effects(adapted_epitaxial,response = 'ybar',                     exclude_vars = c('s2','lns2')) interaction_effects(adapted_epitaxial,response = 'ybar',                     exclude_vars = c('A','s2','lns2'),                     n_columns=3)

what: Main Effects Plot for a Factorial Design
title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Main effect plots factor factorial design
code: main_effects(original_epitaxial,              response='s2',              exclude_vars = c('ybar','lns2')) main_effects(original_epitaxial,              response='s2',              exclude_vars = c('A','ybar','lns2'),              color_palette = 'viridis',              n_columns=3)

what: Contour Plots for Response Surface Methodology
title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Using gg_rsm can obtain contour plots display fitted surface rsm object. best use rsm object one defined , plots produced using information rsm object. gg_rsm includes ... argument additional arguments rsm::contour.lm, see rsm::contour.lm details arguments. default contour plots produce black white color  filled=TRUE, viridis color scheme applied.
code: heli.rsm <- rsm::rsm(ave ~ SO(x1, x2, x3, x4),                       data = rsm::heli) gg_rsm(heli.rsm,form = ~x1+x2+x3,        at = rsm::xs(heli.rsm),        n_columns=2) #> Warning: The dot-dot notation (`..level..`) was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `after_stat(level)` instead. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the ggDoE package. #>   Please report the issue at <https://github.com/toledo60/ggDoE/issues>. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated. gg_rsm(heli.rsm,form = ~x1+x2+x3,        at = rsm::xs(heli.rsm),        filled = TRUE,        n_columns=2)

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: Pareto plot bar graph bars ordered size effect. addition, cutoff line(s) added margin error () simultaneous margin error (SME) effects.  half_normal() function seven methods compute pseudo standard errors. example, consider ‘Daniel’ construction method using significance level \(\alpha=0.1\). Default arguments method “Lenth” alpha = 0.05.  one uses showplot=FALSE argument, list returned calculated PSE,,SME well data used construct pareto plot.

title: Overview of ggDoE
text: function output two dimensional projections Latin hypercube design. example generating random Latin hypercube design using R package lhs  example maximin Latin hypercube design red color points grid (default setting)
code: set.seed(10) random_LHS <- lhs::randomLHS(n=15, k=4) pair_plots(random_LHS,n_columns=3,grid = TRUE) maximin_LHS <- lhs::maximinLHS(n=15, k=4) pair_plots(maximin_LHS,n_columns=3,point_color = 'red')

title: Modern Graphs for Design of Experiments with ggplot2
text: can install: latest release CRAN development version GitHub
code: install.packages('ggDoE') if (!require("remotes")) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("toledo60/ggDoE")

title: Modern Graphs for Design of Experiments with ggplot2
text: ggDoE ’ll able generate common plots used Design Experiments ggplot2. following plots currently available: Alias Matrix Box-Cox Transformation Lambda Plot Boxplots Regression Diagnostic Plots Half-Normal Plot Interaction Effects Plot Factorial Design Main Effects Plot Factorial Design Contour Plots Response Surface Methodology Pareto Plot Two Dimensional Projections Latin Hypercube Design following datasets/designs included ggDoE tibbles: adapted_epitaxial: Adapted epitaxial layer experiment obtain book “Experiments: Planning, Analysis, Optimization, 2nd Edition” original_epitaxial: Original epitaxial layer experiment obtain book “Experiments: Planning, Analysis, Optimization, 2nd Edition” aliased_design: D-efficient minimal aliasing design obtained article “Efficient Designs Minimal Aliasing Bradley Jones Christopher J. Nachtsheim”
code: library(ggDoE)

title: Color Map on Correlations — alias_matrix
text: design Design experiment (Without response) midpoint midpoint value (0,1) split color scheme three colors digits number digits round correlation values. Default 3 color_palette character string indicating color map option use. Eight options available: "viridis","cividis","magma","inferno","plasma","rocket","mako","turbo" alpha alpha transparency, number [0,1] direction Sets order colors scale. 1, default, colors ordered darkest lightest. -1, order colors reversed showplot logical indicating show correlation plot. false, correlation/alias matrix returned. Default TRUE

title: Color Map on Correlations — alias_matrix
text: correlation matrix main effects interaction effects model.matrix. Alias matrix also returned

code: alias_matrix(design=aliased_design)  alias_matrix(design=aliased_design, color_palette = "plasma")  alias_matrix(design=aliased_design, color_palette = "magma", direction = -1)

Default seq(-2,2,1/10) showlambda Default TRUE, show lambda values plot lambdaSF Digits round lambda values shown plot showplot Default TRUE, false plot shown tibble returned 95% confidence interval lambda lambda value maximizes log-likelihood

title: Box-Cox Transformations — boxcox_transform
text: Box-Cox transformation plot 95% confidence interval lambda values consider

code: model <- lm(s2 ~ (A+B+C+D),data = adapted_epitaxial) boxcox_transform(model,lambda = seq(-5,5,0.2))  boxcox_transform(model,lambda = seq(-5,5,0.2),showplot=FALSE) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   best_lambda lambda_low lambda_high #>         <dbl>      <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1       0.253      -3.99        4.70

what: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
text: Regression Diagnostic Plots ggplot2

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
code: diagnostic_plots(   model,   which_plots = 1:4,   cooksD_type = 1,   standard_errors = FALSE,   point_size = 1.5,   theme_color = "#21908CFF",   n_columns = 2 )

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
text: model Model class "lm" "glm" which_plots Choose diagnostic plots choose .  Options 1 = 'residual vs fitted', 2 = 'Normal-QQ', 3 = 'Scale-location', 4 = 'Residual vs Leverage', 5 = "Cook's Distance". 6 = "Collinearity". Default 1:4 cooksD_type integer 1 4 indicating threshold computed Cook's Distance plot. Default 1. See details threshold computation standard_errors Display confidence interval around geom_smooth, FALSE default point_size Change size points plots theme_color Change color geom_smooth line text labels respective diagnostic plot n_columns number columns grid layout. Default 2

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
text: Regression diagnostic plots

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
text: Plot 5: "Cook's Distance": data point large Cook's distance indicates data point strongly influences fitted values model. default threshold used detecting classifying observations outers \(4/n\) (.e cooksD_type=1) \(n\) number observations. thresholds computed follows: cooksD_type = 1: 4/n cooksD_type = 2: 4/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 3: 1/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 4: 3* mean(cook's distance values) \(n\) number observations \(p\) number predictors. Plot 6: "Collinearity": Conisders variance inflation factor (VIF) multicollinearity:  Tolerance = \(1 - R_j^2\), VIF = (1/Tolerance) \(R_j^2\) coefficient determination regression predictor \(j\) predictors. general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 indicates multicollinearity problem

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
text: Belsley, D. ., Kuh, E., Welsch, R. E. (1980). Regression Diagnostics: Identifying Influential Data Sources Collinearity. New York: John Wiley & Sons. Sheather, S. (2009). modern approach regression R. Springer Science & Business Media.

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — diagnostic_plots
code: model <- lm(mpg ~ wt + am + gear + vs * cyl, data = mtcars) diagnostic_plots(model,which_plots=1:6)

title: Boxplots using ggplot2 — gg_boxplots
text: Boxplots using ggplot2

title: Boxplots using ggplot2 — gg_boxplots
code: gg_boxplots(   data,   x,   y,   group_var = NULL,   jitter_points = FALSE,   horizontal = FALSE,   point_size = 1,   alpha = 1,   color_palette = NA,   direction = 1,   show_mean = FALSE )

title: Boxplots using ggplot2 — gg_boxplots
text: data provided dataset x character string indicating factor data y character string indicating response data group_var character string indicating groups facet_wrap jitter_points Overlay jittered points boxplots. Default FALSE. horizontal Determine whether change orientation plot. Default FALSE point_size Change size points (outliers) boxplots alpha alpha transparency, number [0,1] color_palette character string indicating color map option use. Eight options available: "viridis","cividis","magma","inferno","plasma","rocket","mako","turbo" direction Sets order colors scale. 1, default, colors ordered darkest lightest. -1, order colors reversed show_mean Display mean boxplot. Default FALSE

title: Boxplots using ggplot2 — gg_boxplots
text: Boxplots created ggplot2

title: Boxplots using ggplot2 — gg_boxplots
code: data <- ToothGrowth data$dose <- factor(data$dose,levels = c(0.5, 1, 2),labels = c("D0.5", "D1", "D2")) gg_boxplots(data,y= "len",x= "dose",alpha=0.6)  gg_boxplots(data,y = "len",x= "dose",group_var = "supp", alpha=0.6,color_palette = 'viridis',jitter_points=TRUE)

what: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm

text: GLM Diagnostic Plots ggplot2

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
code: gg_glm(   model,   discrete_edm,   which_plots = 1:4,   cooksD_type = 1,   standard_errors = FALSE,   point_size = 1.1,   theme_color = "#008EA0FF",   n_columns = 2 )

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
text: model Model class "glm" discrete_edm Logical value exclusively specify discrete EDM chosen build model. Quantile residuals used instead Deviance/Pearson residuals plots Discrete EDMs which_plots Choose diagnostic plots choose .  Options 1 = "Residuals vs Fitted"; 2 = "Working Responses vs Linear Predictors"; 3 = "Normal Q-Q"; 4 = "Outlier Detection"; 5 = "Half norm plot using leverages"; 6 = "Half norm plot using Cook's Distance"; 7 = "Cook's Distance"; 8 = "DFFITS"; 9 = "VIF" cooksD_type integer 1 4 indicating threshold computed Cook's Distance plot. Default 1. See details threshold computation standard_errors Display confidence interval around geom_smooth, FALSE default point_size Change size points plots theme_color Change color geom_smooth line text labels respective diagnostic plot n_columns number columns grid layout. Default 2

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
text: GLM diagnostic plots

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
text: Check assumptions systematic component GLM: Plot 1: trends appear, systematic component can improved. usually involves 1 combination following: (1) changing link fucntion, (2) adding new predictor variables, /(3) transforming current predictor variables model. Plot 2: plot roughly linear, another link function might appropriate. Check assumptions random component - EDM distribution - GLM: Plot 3: points close line, EDM distribution may appropriate. quantile residuals used since exact normal distribution appropriate EDM chosen. Check outliers influential points: Plot 4: |residual| > 3, observation flagged outlier. Plot 5 & 6: Observations deviate greatly rest data potential outliers. necessary points fall red line since leverages cook's distance values strictly expected postive normal distribution. 5 observations largest values labelled plot. Plot 7: Check outliers Cook's Distance. data point large Cook's distance indicates data point strongly influences fitted values model. default threshold used detecting classifying observations outliers \(4/n\) (.e cooksD_type = 1) \(n\) number observations. thresholds computed follows: cooksD_type = 1: 4/n cooksD_type = 2: 4/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 3: 1/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 4: 3 * mean(cook's distance values) \(n\) number observations \(p\) number predictors. Plot 8: Check outliers DFFITS, considers much fitted value observation changes model fitted data model fitted obervation omitted. |DFFITS| > \(2 * sqrt((parameters + 1) / (observations - parameters - 1))\), observation flagged influential. Check collinearity: Plot 9: Check collinearity variance inflation factor (VIF). Tolerance = \(1 - R_j^2\), VIF = \(1 / Tolerance\), \(R_j^2\) coefficient determination regression predictor j predictors. general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 indicates multicollinearity problem.

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
text: Weisberg, S.: Applied Linear Regression. John Wiley Sons, New York (1985) Pierce, D.., Shafer, D.W.: Residuals generalized linear models. Journal American Statistical Association 81, 977–986 (1986) Williams, D..: Generalized linear models diagnostics using deviance single-case deletions. Applied Statistics 36(2), 181–191 (1987) McCullagh, P., Nelder, J..: Generalized Linear Models, second edn. Chapman Hall, London (1989) Dunn, P.K., Smyth, G.K.: Randomized quantile residuals. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics 5(3), 236–244 (1996) Dunn, P.K., Smyth, G.K. Generalized Linear Models Examples R. Springer Texts Statistics, 297-327 (2018)

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
text: Mo Amiri moamiristat@protonmail.com

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_glm
code: model <- glm(Volume ~ Girth + Height, family = Gamma(link = "log"), data = trees)  # Default plots returned gg_glm(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 1:4) #> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x'   # Half norm plots gg_glm(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 5:6)   # Cook's Distance & DFFITS gg_glm(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 7:8)   # Collinearity gg_glm(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 9, n_columns = 1)

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_lm
text: model Model class "lm" "glm" which_plots Choose diagnostic plots choose .  Options 1 = 'residual vs fitted', 2 = 'Normal-QQ', 3 = 'Scale-location', 4 = 'Residual vs Leverage', 5 = "Cook's Distance". 6 = "Collinearity". Default 1:4 cooksD_type integer 1 4 indicating threshold computed Cook's Distance plot. Default 1. See details threshold computation standard_errors Display confidence interval around geom_smooth, FALSE default point_size Change size points plots theme_color Change color geom_smooth line text labels respective diagnostic plot n_columns number columns grid layout. Default 2

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_lm
text: Regression diagnostic plots

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_lm
text: Plot 5: "Cook's Distance": data point large Cook's distance indicates data point strongly influences fitted values model. default threshold used detecting classifying observations outers \(4/n\) (.e cooksD_type=1) \(n\) number observations. thresholds computed follows: cooksD_type = 1: 4/n cooksD_type = 2: 4/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 3: 1/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 4: 3* mean(cook's distance values) \(n\) number observations \(p\) number predictors. Plot 6: "Collinearity": Conisders variance inflation factor (VIF) multicollinearity:  Tolerance = \(1 - R_j^2\), VIF = (1/Tolerance) \(R_j^2\) coefficient determination regression predictor \(j\) predictors. general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 indicates multicollinearity problem

title: Regression Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — gg_lm
text: Belsley, D. ., Kuh, E., Welsch, R. E. (1980). Regression Diagnostics: Identifying Influential Data Sources Collinearity. New York: John Wiley & Sons. Sheather, S. (2009). modern approach regression R. Springer Science & Business Media.

text: GLM Diagnostic Plots ggplot2

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
code: glm_diagnostic_plots(   model,   discrete_edm,   which_plots = 1:4,   cooksD_type = 1,   standard_errors = FALSE,   point_size = 1.1,   theme_color = "#008EA0FF",   n_columns = 2 )

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
text: model Model class "glm" discrete_edm Logical value exclusively specify discrete EDM chosen build model. Quantile residuals used instead Deviance/Pearson residuals plots Discrete EDMs which_plots Choose diagnostic plots choose .  Options 1 = "Residuals vs Fitted"; 2 = "Working Responses vs Linear Predictors"; 3 = "Normal Q-Q"; 4 = "Outlier Detection"; 5 = "Half norm plot using leverages"; 6 = "Half norm plot using Cook's Distance"; 7 = "Cook's Distance"; 8 = "DFFITS"; 9 = "VIF" cooksD_type integer 1 4 indicating threshold computed Cook's Distance plot. Default 1. See details threshold computation standard_errors Display confidence interval around geom_smooth, FALSE default point_size Change size points plots theme_color Change color geom_smooth line text labels respective diagnostic plot n_columns number columns grid layout. Default 2

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
text: GLM diagnostic plots

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
text: Check assumptions systematic component GLM: Plot 1: trends appear, systematic component can improved. usually involves 1 combination following: (1) changing link fucntion, (2) adding new predictor variables, /(3) transforming current predictor variables model. Plot 2: plot roughly linear, another link function might appropriate. Check assumptions random component - EDM distribution - GLM: Plot 3: points close line, EDM distribution may appropriate. quantile residuals used since exact normal distribution appropriate EDM chosen. Check outliers influential points: Plot 4: |residual| > 3, observation flagged outlier. Plot 5 & 6: Observations deviate greatly rest data potential outliers. necessary points fall red line since leverages cook's distance values strictly expected postive normal distribution. 5 observations largest values labelled plot. Plot 7: Check outliers Cook's Distance. data point large Cook's distance indicates data point strongly influences fitted values model. default threshold used detecting classifying observations outliers \(4/n\) (.e cooksD_type = 1) \(n\) number observations. thresholds computed follows: cooksD_type = 1: 4/n cooksD_type = 2: 4/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 3: 1/(n-p-1) cooksD_type = 4: 3 * mean(cook's distance values) \(n\) number observations \(p\) number predictors. Plot 8: Check outliers DFFITS, considers much fitted value observation changes model fitted data model fitted obervation omitted. |DFFITS| > \(2 * sqrt((parameters + 1) / (observations - parameters - 1))\), observation flagged influential. Check collinearity: Plot 9: Check collinearity variance inflation factor (VIF). Tolerance = \(1 - R_j^2\), VIF = \(1 / Tolerance\), \(R_j^2\) coefficient determination regression predictor j predictors. general rule thumb VIFs exceeding 4 warrant investigation, VIFs exceeding 10 indicates multicollinearity problem.

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
text: Weisberg, S.: Applied Linear Regression. John Wiley Sons, New York (1985) Pierce, D.., Shafer, D.W.: Residuals generalized linear models. Journal American Statistical Association 81, 977–986 (1986) Williams, D..: Generalized linear models diagnostics using deviance single-case deletions. Applied Statistics 36(2), 181–191 (1987) McCullagh, P., Nelder, J..: Generalized Linear Models, second edn. Chapman Hall, London (1989) Dunn, P.K., Smyth, G.K.: Randomized quantile residuals. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics 5(3), 236–244 (1996) Dunn, P.K., Smyth, G.K. Generalized Linear Models Examples R. Springer Texts Statistics, 297-327 (2018)

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
text: Mo Amiri moamiristat@protonmail.com

title: GLM Diagnostic Plots with ggplot2 — glm_diagnostic_plots
code: model <- glm(Volume ~ Girth + Height, family = Gamma(link = "log"), data = trees)  # Default plots returned glm_diagnostic_plots(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 1:4)   # Half norm plots glm_diagnostic_plots(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 5:6)   # Cook's Distance & DFFITS glm_diagnostic_plots(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 7:8)   # Collinearity glm_diagnostic_plots(model, discrete_edm = FALSE, which_plots = 9, n_columns = 1)

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
text: Half-Normal Effects Plots

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
code: half_normal(   model,   method = "Lenth",   alpha = 0.05,   label_active = FALSE,   ref_line = FALSE,   margin_errors = FALSE,   point_color = "#21908CFF",   showplot = TRUE )

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
text: model object class "lm" method Character value. Method calculate PSE. Default Lenth. Options include: Zahn, WZahn, Lenth, RMS, Dong, JuanPena, Daniel. See Details. alpha specify significance level compute margin errors. Numeric significance level, 0 1. Default alpha=0.05 label_active TRUE, active effects labeled effects cross computed margin error (). See method argument details ref_line Dafault TRUE, FALSE abline slope (1/PSE) displayed. Reference line follow along points considered outliers. margin_errors Default FALSE, TRUE cutoffs margin errors () simultaneous margin error (SME) shown point_color Change color points plot showplot Default TRUE, FALSE plot shown tibble returned used create plot along calculated PSE,,SME

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
text: tibble absolute effects half-normal quantiles. ggplot2 version halfnormal plot factorial effects returned

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
text: method argument simple wrapper function PSE() unrepx R package. details can use ?unrepx::PSE(). method arguement implements methods estimating standard error effects estimates unreplicatd designs. methods include Daniel: 68.3rd quantile absolute effects. See Daniel (1959) Dong: RMS method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Dong (1993) JuanPena: iterated median method whereby repeatedly calculate median absolute effects exceed 3.5 times previous median, stabilizes. estimate final median, divided .6578. See Juan Pena (1992). Lenth (Default): SMedian method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Lenth (1989) RMS: Square root mean squared effects. good PSE presence active effects, provided sake comparisons SMedian: 1.5 times median absolute effects Zahn, WZahn: Zahn method slope least-squares line fitted first m points unrepx::hnplot(effects, horiz = FALSE), m = floor(.683 * length(effects)). (line fitted origin.) WZahn method experimental version Zahn's method, based weighted least-squares weights decreasing linearly m - .5 .5, bounded .65m

title: Half-Normal Effects Plots — half_normal
text: Daniel, C (1959) Use Half-Normal Plots Interpreting Factorial Two-Level Experiments. Technometrics, 1(4), 311-341  Dong, F (1993) Identification Active Contrasts Unreplicated Fractional Factorials. Statistica Sinica 3, 209-217  Hamada Balakrishnan (1998) Analyzing Unreplicated Factorial Experiments: Review New Proposals. Statistica Sinica 8, 1-41  Juan, J Pena, D (1992) Simple Method Identify Significant Effects Unreplicated Two-Level Factorial Designs. Communications Statistics: Theory Methods 21, 1383-1403  Lenth, R (1989) Quick Easy Analysis Unrelicated Factorials Technometrics 31(4), 469-473  Zahn, D (1975) Modifications Revised Critical Values Half-Normal Plot. Technometrics 17(2), 189-200

See Daniel (1959) Dong: RMS method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Dong (1993) JuanPena: iterated median method whereby repeatedly calculate median absolute effects exceed 3.5 times previous median, stabilizes. estimate final median, divided .6578. See Juan Pena (1992). Lenth (Default): SMedian method, applied excluding effects exceed 2.5 * PSE(effects, "SMedian") absolute value. See Lenth (1989) RMS: Square root mean squared effects. good PSE presence active effects, provided sake comparisons SMedian: 1.5 times median absolute effects Zahn, WZahn: Zahn method slope least-squares line fitted first m points unrepx::hnplot(effects, horiz = FALSE), m = floor(.683 * length(effects)). (line fitted origin.) WZahn method experimental version Zahn's method, based weighted least-squares weights decreasing linearly m - .5 .5, bounded .65m

title: ggDoE 0.7.9
text: BREAKING renamed diagnostic_plots() gg_lm() renamed gg_boxplots() arguments factor,response x,y, respectively. renamed twoD_projections() pair_plots() CHANGES removed data.table dependency. Now two imports ggplot2 insight MINOR CHANGES switched gridExtra patchwork. functionality change. removed usage deprecated functions aes_string() size arguments package. deprecated ggplot2 version 3.4.0. functionality change

title: ggDoE 0.7.8
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-23 BREAKING gg_boxplots() arguments response,factor,group_var now string characters NEW FUNCTIONS added theme_bw_nogrid(), simple theme settings used throughout ggDoE plots CHANGES removed dplyr dependency favor data.table. data.table significantly less dependencies compared dplyr. added insightto Imports checking required packages installed respective function. insight later used cleaning source code extracting information model objects variables, responses, etc… switched gridExtra unrepx Imports Suggests MINOR CHANGES updated pkgdown website new theme reference structure

title: ggDoE 0.7.7
text: BREAKING renamed argument ncols n_columns functions previously used argument. functions : diagnostic_plots(),gg_rsm(), interaction_effects(),main_effects(),twoD_projections() NEW FEATURES half_normal() new argument point_color change color points diagnostic_plots() new argument cooksD_type change threshold computed Cook’s distance plot (plot #6) CHANGES half_normal() now uses ggrepel::geom_text_repel instead hard-coded geom_text try avoid label overlap

title: ggDoE 0.7.6
text: minor fixes documentation/vignettes moved unrepex Suggests Imports added cran-comments.md

title: ggDoE 0.7.5
text: NEW FEATURES changed appearance gg_boxplots() using fill color. Added new argument jitter_points gg_boxplots() overlay points boxplots. Added initial vignette quick overview ggDoE. Still needs details certain plots

title: ggDoE 0.7.4
text: BUX FIXES Fixed bug twoD_projections() output plot every plot grid

title: ggDoE 0.7.3
text: NEW FUNCTIONS Added new function twoD_projections(). function output two dimensional projections Latin hypercube design. add details documentation future updates. CHANGES Switched gridExtra Imports instead Suggests Description file

title: ggDoE 0.7.2
text: CHANGES Added new plot visualize collinearity variance inflation factor (VIF) diagnostic_plots() function. sixth diagnostic plot.

title: ggDoE 0.7.1
text: BREAKING gg_rsm() restricted model class rsm object. Future updates add back lm class object option. BUG FIXES added error message diagnostic_plots() check insufficient degrees freedom obtain standard errors, t.value. won’t plot diagnostic plots model. MINOR CHANGES Consistent use left-arrow operator (<-) functions package

title: ggDoE 0.7
text: Added NEWS.md file track changes package. CURRENT FUNCTIONS alias_matrix() Color Map Correlations boxcox_transform() Box-Cox transformation plot 95% confidence interval lambda values consider gg_boxplots() Boxplots created ggplot2 diagnostic_plots() Regression Diagnostic Plots ggplot2 gg_rsm() Contour plot(s) fitted linear model ggplot2 RSM object half_normal() halfnormal plot factorial effects lambda_plot() Lambda plot tracing t-staitics across different values lambda main_effects() Main effects plots factor design given specified response pareto_plot() bar plot ordered effects, margin error () simultaneous margin error (SME) cutoffs. viridisPalette() simple wrapper viridisLite package used changing color palette plots
